author: Anne Simons
title: Wild and wet in Alaska
text:
Anne Simons in Chugach National Forest, outside of Seward, Alaska. Photo: Anne Simons Anne Simons in Chugach National Forest, outside of Seward, Alaska. Wild and wet in Alaska 1 / 1 Back to Gallery 
Why I went: I wanted to see the biggest, most wild state in the U.S. 
Don’t miss: The Kenai Peninsula has spectacular glacier-clad peaks, fjords, wildlife on land and sea, and cute towns. 
Don’t bother: Although the train is scenic and relaxing, driving a rental car is easy, faster and allows for spontaneous exploring. 
Coolest souvenir: Moose boots for my grandson, caribou antler beads for me. 
Worth a splurge: Camp Denali North Face Lodge in the interior of Denali, where private vehicles are not allowed: guided hikes, four-star cuisine, eco-conscious management. 
Wish I’d packed: A rain cover for my day pack. It’s a wet state. The lodge provided rain jackets, pants and hiking gaiters — very helpful in the wet tundra. 
Other comments: August was a good time to visit, with colors appearing in the tundra, blueberries everywhere, wildlife actively feeding to prepare for winter, and no mosquitoes. Top Stories
